title: Two Napa Icons, Beaulieu Vineyards & Stags’ Leap Winery, Celebrate Big Years
text:
This year marks the 80th anniversary of one of the first true cult Cabernets of Napa Valley, from Beaulieu Vineyard.

Text size

A hundred of Beaulieu Vineyard’s best customers and closest friends are crowded onto the lawn of the winery’s historic Rutherford House, in Rutherford, Calif., eagerly awaiting the arrival of Trevor Durling. Durling, just the 5th chief winemaker for Beaulieu since its debut at the turn of the 20th century, jauntily rolls up in a 1925 Cadillac originally owned by the winery’s founder, Georges de Latour.

As grand a spectacle as it was, the crowd wasn’t there for the car. They were there for taste of the 2016 Georges de Latour Private Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon, the 80th anniversary of one of the first true cult Cabernets of Napa Valley.

“The Georges de Latour gained a name for itself very quickly, it was the pride and joy of the American wine industry,” Durling says. “It truly set the bar of quality for the entire region.”

Durling says the wine was commonly served not only at major social events but at formal state dinners, an early oenophilic emissary for the fledgling American wine industry across the globe.

The 80th anniversary release is a stunner, the result of what Durling calls a “fantastic vintage across the board, and one of the best GDLs ever made.” The wine offers a velvety mouthfeel with dark chocolate and cocoa powder, as well as tannic, spicy oak and a touch of tart cherries and acid here in its youth.

You’ll also find what has become a hallmark of Beaulieu Vineyards, what’s referred to as Rutherford dust, a signature tasting note from the Rutherford AVA. As Durling explains, it’s “the texture and flavor profile of tannins that are unique to this region,” developing a sort of structured tannic mouthfeel with that dark, dry cocoa powder.

The term was apparently coined by the legendary Beaulieu winemaker André Tchelistcheff, known as “the maestro,” who was responsible for much of the across-the-board quality improvements that took the entire Napa Valley from fringe region to world class status. “He’s probably the most important winemaker in the history of Napa valley,” Durling says. “It’s amazing how much comes back to André.”

Trevor Durling is just the 5th chief winemaker for Beaulieu since its debut at the turn of the 20th century. Beaulieu Vineyards

Beaulieu’s big bash isn’t the only anniversary celebration for Napa Valley wine this year though. Stags’ Leap Winery is celebrating the 125th anniversary of the estate’s first vintage from 1893. The two wineries are under the umbrella of Treasury Wine Estates, which also counts producers such as Sterling Vineyards and Beringer Vineyards among its Napa portfolio.

Winemaker Christophe Paubert has had the reins at Stags’ for the past decade, and a beautiful 2018 harvest neatly coincided with that anniversary. “Last year was the best harvest I’ve seen here,” Paubert says.

It’s fortuitous timing for a blockbuster release from the vintage in the years ahead, with Paubert hinting the special bottle will likely be an estate Petite Sirah. “We are one of the references in North America for Petite Sirah,” Paubert says. “For people who know about it, it’s a passion wine.”

Petite Sirah was planted on the property even before the winery was founded in 1893. Today, the Stags’ estate actually has a small Petite Sirah vineyard planted in 1929, the majestically old, knotty vines growing straight up from the ground. The plot is 85% Petite Sirah, with another 16 varieties sprinkled in, and is picked together for the Ne Cede Malis Petite Sirah label. The 2016 offering was gorgeous and plush, well rounded with a mix of bright fruits and acid as well as light tannins.

“Ne Cede Malis” is a Latin phrase which translates to “don’t give in to misfortune” the motto of Stags’ Leap founder Horace Chase. While there doesn’t seem to be much misfortune to be found in a standout vintage such as 2018, it was only the year prior when the devastating wildfires rampaged through California wine country.

Stags’ Leap Winery is celebrating the 125th anniversary of the estate’s first vintage from 1893. Stags’ Leap Winery

The Stags’ estate was barely spared thanks to the intervention of four fire trucks as the blaze began encroaching on its property. While only a small percentage of the winery’s total vineyards, the loss would have been devastating. “This is our soul,” Paubert says of the estate.

Of course, there are always challenges when it comes to wine. For Paubert, it’s a delicate balancing act between old school tradition and the application of fine-tuned scientific practices. “For me, wine is a mix of science and the human element,” Paubert says. “You can read volumes of the science of making wine, but then not know how to make wine. Ultimately, what I look for is a pure expression of the fruit.”

Durling balances on the same tightrope. “We pride ourselves on very traditional winemaking,” he says. “But we combine that with the latest technology to really bring the best out of our vineyards, to do them the best justice.”

In today’s world of instant gratification, another tightrope to walk is to release wines that satisfy on two fronts, or two timelines—being good the day they’re available yet even better far down the road. “The modern winemaking challenge is figuring out how to make a wine that you can age, but that you can also enjoy right now,” Durling says.

Most consumers don’t want to wait a decade for the wine they’re buying today. Though, sometimes patience has its merits. “I guarantee that you can lay this down for 50 years,” Durling says of the 2016 Georges de Latour. More practically, he recommends holding off at least five years. If you can.
description: 2019 marks major anniversaries for the two cult wineries
